text:
Mr. James Etheridge, Jr.
March 23, 1965
Page 2
from all sides. The same is true with Alan MacIntyre and the engineers. I
think the general morale and rapport increased notably in these two groups.
The television meetings were extremely helpful, but this is true only because
Chuck Marquis literally took them over. He had many meaningful reports to
make - so many, in fact, that we had to reschedule other meetings to include
them all. Marjorie Newman's radio meetings were very well planned and very
well executed. I'm afraid the attendance at some of her sessions was hurt by
the occasional schedule changes that seemed prudent at the time they were made.
I regret that I missed getting a report from Jim Petersen about his sessions.
Finally, one personal note if I may, I enjoyed working with the session
immensely. If there was any major error, it was the delayed distribution of
the program schedule. However, I can say in all honesty that so many events
developed right on the scene at the conference that I am confident we could not
have adhered to any predetermined schedule unless we simply did so blindly and
doggedly against better judgment. I appreciate your appointing me as conference
chairman and look forward to working with you again.
With best wishes.
Sincerely,
J ohxi' Young
Conference Chairman
JY/af
cc: Mr. Harold E. Hill
